 Not trying to be sarcastic, but this encompasses many things/ideas/beliefs.

Big Orn

You are right...too general...sorry, can't think of a better way to put it.

 In general: Religious intolerance is no different than opinions in sports, or horse-breaking, or planting a garden.
 "It has been done this way for years!", is one thing.
 
 How about interracial marriage - remember when that was taboo? Still is in some areas - religion or no.
 
 But, religion is a belief and does not necessarily mean the God of Abraham or the sun goddess or Wakan Tanka.
greg 79 f150

Do you believe that religious intolerance is borne of brainwashing?
 
 Why or why not?

 
 I dont believe intolerance of religion is a result of direct brainwashing in the purest form, no. I do believe some people that are intolerant to religion may be that way because of the environment they were raised in . A non- believing family will have a higher percentage of offspring that will grow up to be non believers , and along the same theme, offspring brought up in a Christian homes will have a higher percentage of Christian adults probaly. That could be interpreted as a brainwashing of sorts. Kind of like kids raised up by parents that drive nothing but Fords, then those kids grow up and buy nothing but Fords, just products of their environment, so to speak. 
 
 Religous intolerance is usually a trait of grown adults that have been in the world long enough to acquire knowledge and facts on subjects they are curious about. One of the ways that people become intolerant of religion is when one tries to rationalize it , make it in to a "proven" fact of record, make it logical with complete reasoning , or make it a composite matter, that they can touch or see. This is when the problems start , none of the listed are easy to do , some will be impossible to achieve by man. 
 
 Religion is largely based on unseen faith in doctrines, doctrines that were written by inspired men, years ago. Once again, they have to "prove" these doctrines to themselves, and these doctrines do not have the luxury of having a "opening and signing" at our local bookstores by the living authors . Sorry, a overly simplistic and long post, but its all I got in me, :) all jmo
unkerpaulie

In general: Religious intolerance is no different than opinions in sports, or horse-breaking, or planting a garden.
 "It has been done this way for years!", is one thing.
 
 How about interracial marriage - remember when that was taboo? Still is in some areas - religion or no.
 
 But, religion is a belief and does not necessarily mean the God of Abraham or the sun goddess or Wakan Tanka.

 i agree with this. religious intolerance really boils down to a difference in opinions. its not much difference from what we see coming from political supporters, patriots, artists or sports fans (like ron said). once anybody feels strongly about anything, they will resist a difference in opinion. sometimes they become hostile and attack opposing views. sometimes they become violent. it really has nothing to do with religion in particular. there are some people that let their passion and beliefs dictate their actions, for better or worse. but this occurs on every level of life and among all kinds of people

I dont believe intolerance of religion is a result of direct brainwashing in the purest form, no. I do believe some people that are intolerant to religion may be that way because of the environment they were raised in . A non- believing family will have a higher percentage of offspring that will grow up to be non believers , and along the same theme, offspring brought up in a Christian homes will have a higher percentage of Christian adults probaly.

 
 
 I'm sorry, I'm a bit confused by what you mean as "non-believers." Would those who do not subscribe fully to one religious dogma included in that group? 
 I mean to say those who do not identify with any one religious lable, such as Catholic, Baptist, Lutheran...etc. 
 
 
 That could be interpreted as a brainwashing of sorts. Kind of like kids raised up by parents that drive nothing but Fords, then those kids grow up and buy nothing but Fords, just products of their environment, so to speak.

 
 Although I don't disagree that it is likely, but I really don't believe it's the rule. 
 My parents are of mixed religious backgrounds, but allowed their children to "find religion" in whatever way we were comfortable with. My parents did always drive Fords, but my sybling and I do not. My sybling has never owned a Ford, probably a form of rebelion. I on the other hand have owned a Ford, but am not loyal to any specific car manufacturer. 
 (I'm just using your annology...sorry) 
 
 
Religous intolerance is usually a trait of grown adults that have been in the world long enough to acquire knowledge and facts on subjects they are curious about. One of the ways that people become intolerant of religion is when one tries to rationalize it , make it in to a "proven" fact of record, make it logical with complete reasoning , or make it a composite matter, that they can touch or see. This is when the problems start , none of the listed are easy to do , some will be impossible to achieve by man.

 
 Or could it possibly be moreover intollerance (which indeed exists in adults) comes from a narrow world view. Lack of cultural diversity, knowledge of other ways of thinking or living. 
 
 
 
Religion is largely based on unseen faith in doctrines, doctrines that were written by inspired men, years ago. Once again, they have to "prove" these doctrines to themselves, and these doctrines do not have the luxury of having a "opening and signing" at our local bookstores by the living authors . Sorry, a overly simplistic and long post, but its all I got in me, :) all jmo

 
 Good analogy there. 
 I'm not attempting to argue here, I'm just curious.

Do you believe that religious intolerance is borne of brainwashing?
 
 Why or why not?

 Tolerance is something a lot of new age/feel good people prance about with. In the end one can not tolerate all beliefs and at the same time adhere to a particular set of beliefs, oneself.
 
 I accept Christian beliefs, therefore I will not tolerate religions/beliefs that promote;
 
 a-homicide - the Thuggee of India
 b-child abuse - the Family, aka "The Children of God"
 and a host of other beliefs. I can not, because they are incompatible with my own beliefs. They are so incompatible that I can't just say "Okay, if you want to believe in what you believe, that's okay for you"

 Montalbah,
 
 What about Judiasm? Not that I'm asking you to accept other religions, but allow others who believe in that venue to practice it without interference. 
 
 An example would be like people who want to "witness" to me and have me convert to their way of religious belief. I mean, there was the spanish inquisition, the persecution of the religious by the romans, and of course old WWII that either tried to convert these people (through torture) or even kill them (genoside).
 
 Now if you look at it with these things in mind, someone trying to witness to me is not going to make me turn away from my faith anymore than torture or genoside would. So why would someone who just wants to share their beliefs, be able to make me willingly turn away from my faith? Logic says this will not happen to me.

 Hi Justincredible, my definition of a non believer is one that does NOT believe in a higher power ( God) , a deity, or supreme being acquainted with any religion . If one believes in any sort of spiritual after life , then I could not in all honesty, say that person is a non - believer. I think you may be taking my Ford analogy a bit to serious though, it was just my overly simplistic analogy of how children can grow up and be influenced in their choice of religion , or not, by their parents . There are always holes in the fabrics of interpretations, whenever people debate , mine included. :) 
 
 As to your reference to other sources of intolerance , such as people not being cultural diverse, people with tunnel vision and close mindness, those are good points indeed. I believe all of those can promote religous intolerance in our society. But one would have to look at how the person as a individual, got to be intolerant of religion , from hearing their personal experiences I believe. There are way too many variables that happen in peoples lives , that make them intolerable to religion, for one to make a generalization about it . Everyone has their own story I am sure, and most will stick to it, :)

montalban

I see that in your eyes someone who does not speak out directly against something is then supporting it?

 No, I see it that when someone enters this debate going on about how we should all be tolerant of all religions - and I post some examples and challenge people to answer whether they support them, they might want to answer. I have not said that silence equals support - however that is an inference many have made in the past - if you don't speak out against abuse, you are in effect condoning it.
 Anyway, none have replied to me on this thread except you, and JoeBrummer.
 JoeBrummer tried to redefine one of these intolerable groups by suggesting it wasn't a religion at all, but a cult.
 And you enter this debate because some how you think I've made a personal attack on you. You instead mask this in terms of me being on 'the attack' when you lack the insight to see the attacks you yourself have made, in broad terms, and personal ones - lest you feel only you have the right to do this (see the way you've questioned whether I as an Australian have a right to enter a debate on Civil Rights).
 Further, you tried to point score on the 'metric system', and on the 'god, country, apple-pie' phrasing of another poster. Even here you don't deal with the issues, but are determined to personalise this - I must do so in response.
 
Why do you persist in harassing posters in this manor? 

 Do you feel 'harassed? Have I directed these post about 'the family' at you specifically? Looking back over the posts, I've replied directly to LadyWolf and JoeBrummer, now you. How is it that you feel harassed?
 If you feel that I've posted these questions directly to you (and I don't see that I have) - then why do you persist in not actually answering the questions I put? If you feel that these questions weren't put to you, then how is it that you feel harassed? Maybe you're tele-empathic? :)
 Perhaps because if some of the 'free-thinkers' admit that in fact they don't tolerate all beliefs that the whole reason for this thread will collapse... which was in fact an exercise to draw out Christians who actually ARE committed to principles beyond the parameters their own feelings of what is right or wrong.
 
And what exactly was that crack at her spelling?

 I don't follow this, lest you refer to a poster writing Judiasm. It's to determine if in fact this poster is referring to Judaism, or something else entire. It did sound funny though.... Judiasm. You don't see it as funny. Big deal.
 
Maybe someone needs a time-out.

 You're free to leave. Or, you might return, and actually answer some of the questions put to others. You might just resort to generalised and sweeping-statements, as you've done so in the past. I think you're very angry about a lot of things, especially about some upstart Australian who argues with facts and shows you up on issues about America. And you live there! :)
 
 If you want, here's the question for you... do you support the practices of the Hindus in Suttee, or of animists in female genital mutilation, or the 'free love' practices of "the Family"? Your lack of response won't surprise me, however, I will not draw an inference that your silence equals support.

I would still like an answer from Ladywolf.
 
 Does she tolerate all religious beliefs?
joebrummer

I would still like an answer from Ladywolf.
 
 Does she tolerate all religious beliefs?

 
 
 
 Does anyone tolerate "all" beliefs?
Ladywolf

I would still like an answer from Ladywolf.
 
 Does she tolerate all religious beliefs?

 
 Do I tolerate all religious beliefs...of the relgious belief systems I have seen, I don't have any problems with them unless they interfere with my religious practices.
 
 Specific examples of the above statement would be if...
 
 someone came and knocked on my door and attempted to convert me. I find this to be an insult. If I wanted to be coverted to their religion, I would seek them out, they wouldn't need to knock at my door. I do realize that knocking on people's doors and trying to get them to covert is part of their belief system, that's not my problem. They can go knock on someone else's door...there are plenty of other doors to knock on.
 
 As far as me interfering with other's religious belief's I don't have a problem with them. When they attempt to try and distort the truth as I know it, to manipulate me to believe something that I previously thought was false, I am tolerant too (i.e. trying to get me to believe that America is a Christian Nation).
 
 I have problem with people walking up to vulnerable people and turning their belief system upside down without thinking of the consequences...to destroy someone's belief system is a horrible thing to do.
 
 Other than that, I think people should be left to their own belief systems.
Anastasia

Does anyone tolerate "all" beliefs?

 I would think that I tolerate "all" beliefs...
 with an exception to something crazy that could bring harm to somone ie Jim Jones and the like, or the Heavens Gate people...
 There are so many wacky cults out there and if it floats their boats.. so be it.
 But I would never judge someone because of their beliefs, I have friends from many different belief systems, I have studied many belief systems and I respect their choices.
 I live in America and no matter how anyone defines seperation of church and state it always broils down to one thing.. Freedom from religion meaning anyone at anytime can believe what they choose or more importantly not believe..
 I think there are extremists in every religion and that I do have conflict with, anyone who is going to pound on my door AFTER I have made my stance clear is rude, and gives their religion a bad rep INHO.
 ;)
